text: From the time of Joe McCarthy to the Trial of the Chicago Seven, censorship is always justified on the basis of some passing threat. Eventually the hysteria recedes and the power-mad goons who repressed speech are revealed for what they are.

Free speech has never meant “anything goes”. Supreme Court has defined 9 major exceptions including incitement, fighting words, defamation, and fraud. Big Tech could have operated within that framework. Instead they’ve usurped the power to define allowed speech. Real issue.

text: Now the argument is shifting from “build your own app” to “build your own OS”. Yeah right. This is selective obliviousness to the idea of market power. If Apple and Google were colluding to raise prices, everyone would understand.

Let’s stop pretending that Big Tech even has “moderation policies”. They are making it up as they go, responding to pressure from above and below. They are adrift in terms of principle, which is what happens when you reject free speech.

text: @solonang A city is not a company, but in the era of remote work, cities are being subject to increasing competitive pressure. The successful cities will react accordingly by adopting a customer-centric model of government. Unsuccessful cities will remain captured by special interests.

@shabhinav913 Churn is when a subscriber cancels — or in this case, when a resident leaves a city. Churn notes track the reasons why and look for common denominators. When you see a common denominator, you fix it.

8/ The good news is that the SaaS playbook is easy to implement. It’s been done thousands of times. The question is whether there’s the political will to do it. Ultimately voters are going to have to demand a new crop of politicians who have a customer success mindset. //

7/ Bad cities/politicians will scoff at this analogy. They are too good for sales. They’ve lost sight of their customer. They’re trapped in legacy thinking. 

We’ve seen what happens when this happens to a SaaS company: it loses.

6/ R&D - successful cities will plow ARR back into features that enhance the value of the city, creating a virtuous cycle that attracts more ARR. They will listen to customers about what those features should be, not special interests (who are basically suppliers, not customers).

domain.name: Interests and Hobbies Category
domain.description: A grouping of interests and hobbies entities, like Novelty Food or Destinations

text: 5/ Marketing - successful cities will track their NPS score and have an active presence on social media. They will define a vision, maybe even put forth a mission statement. They will understand and enhance their niche in a competitive market for knowledge workers.

4/ CSM - successful cities will instrument churn, try to collect churn notes from people who leave, and work to eliminate the reasons for churn before it happens. They will view CSAT as their key metric.

3/ Sales - successful cities will sell job creators on moving there. That’s why @FrancisSuarez is killing it right now. He’s selling unopposed. It’s pretty easy to win competitive deals when your rivals aren’t even bothering to counter-sell against you.

2/ ARR - successful cities will view taxpayer revenue as an annually recurring subscription by residents who are free to cancel at any time. Accordingly they will try to delight customers, not vilify them. They will focus on delivering a product that people want.

6/ Moral of the story: when a SaaS business has both B2B/Team plans and B2C/Individual plans, break your analysis into two separate buckets. If B2B has compounding cohorts and B2C has deteriorating cohorts, place all the value on B2B and view B2C as lead gen. //

5/ How does Craft value a business like this? We placed 0 value on ARR from the Individual business but valued the Team business at a very high ARR multiple. We led the Series A. VCs that didn’t separate Teams vs Overall may have missed why we are so excited about this one.

4/ Most importantly, revenue cohorts for the Team product were compounding over time whereas revenue cohorts for the Individual product were shrinking. This is the key point: The Team product was creating a growing revenue base while the Individual base was deteriorating.

3/ The Individual plan had about 60% annual revenue retention, which is poor (but not uncommon for Individual plans). The Team product had roughly 200%+ net revenue retention, which is fantastic. https://t.co/ybUq6orBD3

2/ Craft evaluated a Series A investment that had 85% annual revenue retention across the Overall business. It didn't look particularly impressive. 

But when we separated cohorts for Individual and Team plans, we saw a very different picture. The average masked two extremes.

text: 5/ The magic of B2B/Team SaaS is in those compounding cohorts. By contrast, B2C/Individual SaaS has shrinking cohorts. 50%/year revenue churn is not uncommon so the SaaS vendor is rebuilding its business from scratch every 2 years! Hard to build a very valuable company this way.

4/ Third, Seat Expansion.

Team plans add new seats as the product spreads within a company, creating revenue expansion. As a result, successful Team products have “net negative churn,” meaning that expansion exceeds churn. 

E.g. this beautiful chart from Slack’s S-1: https://t.co/xkM3UDn0gh

text:
3/ Second, Retention. 

Team products are stickier than Individual products. Multiplayer mode is more engaging than single-player mode. And it's harder to leave. 

Account-level churn rates for Individual plans are typically 5% per month, but only 1-2% per month for Team plans.

2/ First, Deal Sizes.

Team products have larger contract values (b/c multiple seats). Small CVs of Individual products often can't justify the cost of a sales team. Unless the Individual product is highly viral, it will be easier to build distribution for a Team product.

text: 5/ Slack eventually got this right but the initial anti-sales mentality did cost them some time. Let’s put this in context: they had ~7 years of otherwise flawless execution. But still, the sooner that product-first SaaS founders embrace sales, the better off they will be.

4/ Thus it’s incumbent on the startup to quickly convert bottom-up traction into deals. Bottom-up is great for top-of-funnel but you still need a sales team to close. Enterprises don’t self-serve. This was a central learning of Yammer.

text: 3/ Bottom-up works best for new categories of software. Once IT makes a wall-to-wall decision, it settles the matter. In other words, bottom-up works best when there’s no top-down. Nature abhors a vacuum. In this case, an IT vacuum gets filed by “shadow IT.”

2/ Bottom-up is still the best way into enterprises for startups. If Slack had to sell top-down, they wouldn’t have gotten anywhere. Especially true for products whose advantage is usability, rather than checkboxes. “Show, not tell”. Proof of the pudding is in the eating of it.

text: 7/ Since OTE is 20% of sales, the fully-loaded cost of an AE will represent 25% cost of sales. Sales overhead will typically cost another 15-25% of sales. That means you can spend about 50% of New ARR on Marketing CAC (lead gen) and still keep your payback under 12 months.

text: 6/ If an AE is unable to generate at least $400k/year in New ARR (implying $80k-100k OTEs), a sales-driven distribution strategy may not pencil.

5/ “Quota Capacity” refers to the total team quota. For example, 10 AEs with quotas of $500k each = $5M QC. 

Avg team attains about 70% of QC. 

A manager’s quota should be set at 80% of QC. 

If the team is hitting 80%+ of QC, that’s a sign you can hire more AEs.

text:
4/ For simplicity, I’ve presented annual numbers, but quarterly sales plans are actually ideal. (I explain why in The Cadence.) Just divide the numbers by 4 to put your AEs on a quarterly plan.

https://t.co/zu9vxYNUOq

3/ Taken together, these standards generate a third rule: the typical quota will equal 10x base salary. I call this the Rule of 10. This generates the following pay scale for AEs: https://t.co/vgQhWVpWml

2/ There are actually a number of simple math-based rules that you can use to set up a sales team. 

First, the standard commission rate for SaaS products is 10%. 

Second, in constructing an OTE for an AE, a 50/50 split between base and variable compensation is typical.

The beauty of SaaS is that you already know how you're going to make money (ARR). There's still some figuring out to do around pricing, but that's a lot easier than thrashing around looking for a business model.

Startup pricing involves a tradeoff between simplicity and extraction. In the early stages, it's better to keep it simple because your goal is to avoid friction and prove product-market fit. Later on, you can extract more by adding complexity.

RT @chrishlad: When you should worry about competition👇

@chrishlad If you’re a copy of something else or roadmaps are converging to create that effect. 
If your pricing power threatens to be undercut. 
If sales deals are a heads-up checkbox battle. 
If genuine network effects are in play.
@thogge The tech forest is so big now that it has created room for new animals. The key is to be highly adapted to your own ecology.

Private investors worry too much about competition. If a product is sufficiently distinctive as to carve out its own niche, markets are big enough to support multiple winners. From the outside it looks like one category, from the inside many categories. Bet on distinctiveness. https://t.co/cYeZGXPtPV

text: @suniltom Do you do product goals as part of OKRs? If so, you will want to do Product OKRs at the same time that you prioritize the roadmap. If not, then everyone could be on same schedule.

@suniltom The R in OKRs is for Results, so I would do them right after the quarterly close, when the last set of results are in and you’re planning the next set. Basically the same logic as holding board meetings about 2 weeks into the new quarter.

text:
@SamRBarnett That’s bottom-up. Employees pulled it into the enterprise. Of course you add top-down sales once the pipe is full of leads. 

Every bottom-up SaaS company gets to the same place, which is realizing they need a sales team, no matter how much they swore they wouldn’t.

@robertmclaws @MichaelDTam Finding a new product hook is non-trivial. Melding it with a distribution trick is even harder. Then you need to have the market insight, reverse-engineer the buyer, build the company, and beat competitors. Nothing easy about it.
@robertmclaws @MichaelDTam I absolutely believe that “if you build it, they will come” — assuming you have a product hook and a distribution trick.

@dscheinm Makes sense. I agree that figuring out who their buyer is is the key transition that product-first founders have to make in SaaS. I described the process here:

https://t.co/gB7paDyAqX
Totally true for top-down. For bottom-up, it’s often better just to build it and see who comes. Then reverse-engineer who the buyer is and refine the use cases. https://t.co/srBvCZeqA6

text:
Easy way to make money as an investor:
1) take no early-stage risk.
2) wait for product visionary to emerge in huge industry where incumbents are tech-clueless.
3) bet that the disruption will compound for decades.

Eg:
Tesla vs auto makers 
Amazon vs retail
Netflix vs Hollywood

text:
Key events each quarter on the Cadence:

Month 1:
— Sales Kickoff
— Board Meeting (review last Q’s results while still fresh)
— All-hands: review results & strategy

Month 2:
— Launch Event 
— All-hands: preview before; debrief after

Month 3:
— Product Kickoff
— Sales Close https://t.co/AKHjayQqom

text: The effect of such a feature would go well beyond @SubstackInc. It would create a career path for any aspiring writer. The message: You are not beholden to corporate censors. Focus on building your brand. Don’t compromise your journalistic integrity to fit a narrative.

The antidote to cancel culture is @SubstackInc. 

Feature idea: subscribers should be able to join a wait list for any writer not yet on Substack. The writer can claim the account when they’re ready. 

The message: your subscribers are waiting for you.

Do all your sales reps know how to sell the product roadmap and vision? SaaS startups aren’t just selling today’s version of the product. They’re selling an ongoing subscription. It’s important for customers to know what they will be getting in the future.

Bad leaders don't set deadlines and somehow think more will get done.

Good leaders set internal deadlines, forcing tough prioritization decisions. 

Great leaders send out invitations for a launch event and risk humiliation if the team doesn't hit it.

https://t.co/kPo2gaVTRk

text: There would still be localized hotspots (like nursing homes) where Ro goes above 1. Those would have to be protected in a different way. But for most of society, if Ro < 1, the virus would peter out.

domain.name: Ongoing News Story
domain.description: Ongoing News Stories like 'Brexit'

text: Right now the political debate is dominated by permanent lockdowns vs acceptance (“we have to learn to live with the virus”). If forced to choose, I would choose the latter so society continues. But there is a third path: stringent mask wearing could control the virus (eg Japan).

Designers of viral loops understand that the difference between a viral coefficient of 1.1 and 0.9 is not 0.2 —it’s the difference between going exponential or petering out. Studies now show that a mask requirement reduces Ro under 1. The significance is still under-appreciated.
@mattmireles It’s WHO too. See Vanity Fair article. https://t.co/RSaPeE2zJZ

entity.name: The Last Dance
entity.description: In the fall of 1997, Michael Jordan and the Chicago Bulls allowed a film crew to follow them as they went for their sixth NBA title in eight seasons. That resulted in a stunning portrait of one of the sport's most iconic athletes and a celebrated team. ``The Last Dance'' follows the Bulls' 1997-98 season from start to finish, while also covering the rest of the chapters in Jordan's remarkable career. The 10-part docuseries follows the Jordan timeline from when he was an emerging star on his high school team to becoming a worldwide marketing force and cultural figure. The series takes its name from a phrase coined by then-Bulls coach Phil Jackson, who knew that the season would likely be the final run for the core members of that 1990s Bulls dynasty.

text:
Key recent learnings about covid:
1) Official fatality rate overstated at least 10x because of unreported cases.
2) Risk to 60+ is ~50x risk to under 60.
3) Masks-4-all can reduce Ro <1. 

Continuing to quarantine entire population seems excessive in light of what we now know.

entity.name: The Last Dance
entity.description: In the fall of 1997, Michael Jordan and the Chicago Bulls allowed a film crew to follow them as they went for their sixth NBA title in eight seasons. That resulted in a stunning portrait of one of the sport's most iconic athletes and a celebrated team. ``The Last Dance'' follows the Bulls' 1997-98 season from start to finish, while also covering the rest of the chapters in Jordan's remarkable career. The 10-part docuseries follows the Jordan timeline from when he was an emerging star on his high school team to becoming a worldwide marketing force and cultural figure. The series takes its name from a phrase coined by then-Bulls coach Phil Jackson, who knew that the season would likely be the final run for the core members of that 1990s Bulls dynasty.

How politics in US works:

There’s not enough masks
So to save them for medical workers, gov’t lies about their usefulness,
So the public is slow to demand them
So politicians feel no pressure to produce or require them
So there’s not enough masks. 

Repeat until Twitter corrects

If we had a gigafactory for masks, there would be no crisis.

If masks don’t work, then why is it so important to get them for medical workers?

If masks do work (including for doctors & nurses in hospitals), then why wouldn’t we use them everywhere?

Why isn’t N95-for-all the centerpiece of our response instead of lockdowns?

text:
1/ How to survive a depression: 

If demand for your business suddenly drops 30%, 50%, 80% overnight, what do you do? 

Cut costs by a commensurate amount to stay solvent.

This is very sad and tough to do but the answer is clear.

In addition to providing testing and PPE for workers, we should also consider federally-subsidized hazard pay for essential industries where coworkers have tested positive. We have to protect supply chains as well as paychecks.

Fed Govt needs to create “safe harbor” standard so employers know how to reopen without fear of liability. Eg: if employer tests workers, disinfects site and gives workers PPE, everyone can get back to work. Right now employers don’t know how and when to give the “all clear”. 2//

Many if not most factories, plants, job sites and distribution centers will have at least 1 worker who tests positive. If the only reaction is to close until further notice, it will be disastrous for the economy including food supply chain. 1/

https://t.co/ExwaMrBUhQ

@ddebow Right, you can’t enter into contracts with people you don’t even know, with whom you come into contact for brief moments. So there is an appropriate basis for regulation in a free society. The key is to recognize the externality we can’t see.

In classical law & economics, if soot from your smoke stack dirties my laundry, that‘s an externality. So we regulate it. Infectious respiratory emissions are now a health externality, we just can’t see them as easily as soot. Masks are easy prevention. The law should require it. https://t.co/0LNU48lpA6
Who will be our Salk? https://t.co/J9ZqsCYKXm
@naval Why can’t you keep families together but require them all to quarantine if one is sick? Effectively treat the household as the unit of infection.

domain.description: Ongoing News Stories like 'Brexit'

text:
5/ Binary decisions create polarized outcomes. Iterative decisions create intermediate and improving outcomes. 

The decision needs to be reconceived. 

Less binary and more iterative FTW.
4/ If the decision is conceived as a single binary choice to reopen, the plan will not be sophisticated enough to succeed. We will be cycling in and out of lockdowns as @naval has predicted.

3/ In yellow, high-risk populations stay under SIP. Super-spreader locations (bars, dine-in restaurants, movie theaters) stay closed. 
— green zones can loosen further but have to enforce their borders to make it work.
— same-day test & trace is the precondition to everything.

2/ How do you do that? Make the choice less binary. 

For example:
— define red / yellow / green zones as @balajis has suggested. 
— red zones stay under SIP until exponentiality is controlled.
— yellow zones allow low-risk groups out but they have to wear masks. ...

Buchanan writes that the entire Trump presidency hangs on decision to reopen the economy. Trump says it’s the biggest decision he’s ever had to make. 

What do you do when you have to make an existential decision under conditions of enormous uncertainty? 

Try to derisk it. 1/

text: The “fast” part is also wrong insofar as when things aren’t working, you want to give yourself as much time as possible. I hear too many excuses for why burn can’t be cut. As long as you have runway, you have life and the chance for success. Give yourself the chance.

The point is that being a founder is so hard that as soon as you accept failure as acceptable, you’re more likely to succumb to it. Of course we all know failure is a possibility. But it’s better to act as if it’s not — to burn the boats, psychologically speaking.

@jboehmig Fair enough. My real point is that being a founder is so hard that as soon as you accept failure as acceptable, you’re more likely to succumb to it. Of course we all know failure is a possibility. But it’s better to act as if it’s not — to burn the boats, psychology speaking.

@JonStevensHall I love all the martyrs who are only wearing a mask for *other* people. Yes you should wear a mask for other people; everyone should; in fact it should be required. But a decent mask also protects you. And there’s nothing wrong with that.

For the nitpickers: 
"The primary mode of transmission appears to be through direct or indirect contact of mucous membrane (eyes, nose, or mouth) with infectious respiratory droplets or fomites."
New England Journal of Medicine

text: @_Suthen @hoff CSM should be main point of contact post-close but AE should come back in for renewals or upsells.

@hoff In the early years, I like an AE to own the renewal (at a lower commission rate under separate quota) to maximize opportunity for expansion and minimize risk of churn. But CSMs should be bonused based on their retention rates and contribution to expansion.

A perennial debate in B2B SaaS is who the ideal customer is -- enterprises or SMBs. There’s an Old School view and a New School view on this. I explain here.

https://t.co/U6mwpbkZUJ

@KJMagee Biggest learning was that consumerized approach is great for pipeline generation, but freemium leads don’t convert on their own. So we ended up recreating all the traditional enterprise functions (sales, CSM, marketing) with goal of closing/retaining a “customer for life.”

text: Second, names are important. You have a name. Your company has a name. Presumably your product has a name. If you can’t put a name on what you’re doing or what you’re trying to accomplish, maybe you haven’t thought about it long enough.

Surprised by all the angry, almost entitled responses to my post. Two things to keep in mind: First, the world does not owe you its attention. It’s up to you to convey info in a clear concise manner so people care. Do not blame the audience if they don’t. Work harder to be clear.

To be clear, VCs don’t invest on the basis of a few words. The process is much more involved than that. But if you can’t answer a simple first question without rambling, it’s a bad sign. Great founders know how to be crisp. This matters for marketing even more than fundraising.

text: @michaelglena @hunterwalk Yeah I agree - in the new environment, Series A investors will ask about it, Series C will insist on it, Series B can go either way depending on who they are.
@bornaVC I’m not advocating for early profitability. I’m advocating for early prioritization of unit economics for businesses that have complicated physical-world products and operations.
20/ It should go without saying that tech-enabled startups can still be fantastic businesses -- if they get the unit economics right. //
19/ Founders should plan to be unit-economic positive by the time they raise growth capital. Founders can no longer depend on an endless spigot of funding to defer tough business decisions.

18/ Note that it's not unusual for startups to lose a lot of money in the early days. But the question is what kind of money are they losing? Losing money at the corporate level is ok (all startups do); losing money at the unit level is not.

text: 17/ Trying to re-engineer the unit economics or culture of a business that is already operating at massive scale is brutally hard. Searching for the scalable model when you’re already at scale is a contradiction in terms.

16/ Third, you should prioritize 0 to 1 problems like positive unit economics and a culture of operational excellence before going from 1 to N. Get the operation working at small scale, in one geo, with the right teamwork and culture, before expanding into lots of markets.

text: 10/ So what are the lessons if you’re a tech-enabled startup? First, you’re going to need a proficiency in cost attribution from the beginning. You’ll need to know your unit costs at a much more detailed level than a typical SaaS startup (which doesn’t have meaningful COGS).

9/ As a result, there is now a painful readjustment happening as many of these companies try to fix unit economics and bring their cost structures in line. Valuations are similarly being reappraised for growth that was achieved at the expense of negative unit economics.

8/ Although growth solves many problems at startups, unit economics is not one of them. When you’re losing money on every transaction, you can’t make it up in volume. In fact, the more revenue that a business with negative unit economics generates, the more money it loses.
7/ But they still thought like software companies. Good for innovation, not so good for operational efficiency.

text: 6/ These new “tech-enabled” businesses had major COGS (e.g. leases at WeWork; drivers at Uber) and cost structures more similar to the companies they were disrupting (e.g. commercial landlords; the taxicab industry).

5/ But when software started eating the world, everything changed. Software was just one component of the service being offered. Software might be the disruptive element but it wasn’t the source of unit economics.

3/ When software moved to the cloud, this dynamic didn’t change. Almost all of the production cost is in creating the product for the first user. Aside from hosting, it’s almost free (on an incremental basis) to provision additional users.

text: 1/ How did we get here? The truth is that software startups never had to worry about gross margins until software started eating the world. Gross margins only became a concern once software blended with physical-world products to create new “tech-enabled” business models.

Some thoughts on the topic du jour in tech right now -- the sudden reappraisal of tech-enabled businesses based on gross margins/unit economics. Here's what founders need to know.

The Gross Margin Problem: Lessons for Tech-Enabled Startups https://t.co/NvQ23q3Lpg
@CAristocrat Never took a dime for any of it. You don’t extort desperate companies.

The magic of Silicon Valley is that all employees participate in success and honorable failures are quickly forgiven. But when founders extort obscene payments while employees are fired by the thousands, it invites regulatory scrutiny, imperils the system, and destroys the magic.

Unicorn recipe for entrepreneurs:
1) Pick a job category that’s in-demand or overlooked. 
2) Figure out how to fractionalize the labor so that workers can be hired by the gig, rather than FTE.
3) Develop deep vertical functionality.

Result: hyper-vertical service marketplace.

text:
GO TIGER!

Wasn’t so long ago that his comeback was being portrayed as a psychosis. Remember this?

Great reminder of T.R.’s aphorism “it’s not the critic who counts”. https://t.co/pBvXtv84dF

Great description of what I’ve called a “product hook”. Better to attack the market with a single killer feature or use case than with big complicated plans that fail to gain adoption. Focus on sharpening your wedge into the market, rather than snowplowing it. https://t.co/pBH4vSjmhi

By the way, it’s often Engineering that’s  advocating for the need to stop iterating (eg to do a giant refactor). Don’t buy into the v2 fallacy. Do code cleanup along the way so that tech debt doesn’t overwhelm you. The product will always feel like a prototype.

A team of great engineers regularly shipping code is a form of compounding (ie “the most powerful force in the universe”). This is a major reason startups beat big companies. If it gets broken, your startup is toast. Avoid the excuses, they’re never valid. Just keep shipping.

@Esmussein @joshuaforman @trevorloy @nvca How many of those redlines are truly necessary as opposed to that lawyer’s personal preferences about what’s slightly better?

In traditional investing, there is ‘growth’ and ‘value’. In venture investing, there is ‘story’ and ‘proof’. 

Although investing solely based on proof seems like the obvious thing to do, all the biggest outcomes have required a belief in the story.
I think this explains why Silicon Valley often appears gullible especially compared to places like Wall Street or Hollywood — it’s a high-trust environment.

“You wouldn’t want to live in a world where you couldn’t be conned. Because it would mean you’re living in a world where you never trusted anyone or anything.”
— Ricky Jay https://t.co/9HoPaSxRUz

RT @NTmoney: Fun chat with @davidsacks at last week’s @Token_Summit. 

From Paypal to Ethereum: https://t.co/pU631CBVPr

Only 2 applications of blockchain have been proven at scale:
1) ownership ledger (for bitcoin)
2) fundraising platform (for ICOs)

This is why I’m bullish on blockchain as an ownership ledger and fundraising platform for securities. 

Other apps will arise but harder to predict.

The blockchain is an ownership ledger that guarantees the uniqueness and authenticity of digital assets. Collectibles is a natural use case, and this is a terrific team. Excited to be an investor! https://t.co/sQ0krOBFpT

@Ragnarly @BrendanFWallace @NTmoney @TokenSummit @harbor It’s important to note that @harbor is not blockchaining the title to real estate. We’re tokenizing the cap table of investment vehicles. Digital tokens just replace paper certificates.
@Ragnarly @BrendanFWallace @NTmoney @TokenSummit @harbor It’s good enough to get started. If we need to migrate to another chain down the road, we can.

@Keith_Wasserman @NTmoney @TokenSummit @harbor In @harbor‘s conception, there are no new legal structures. The investor still has a traditional ownership interest such as a share in a REIT, an LP interest in a fund, or a membership interest in an LLC. The token merely evinces that ownership and allows it to be transferred.

@AsherOfLA @villi @jess Fine then why don’t the bike sharing companies offer what they can afford to pay? Bird is the only one so far to pledge daily pickups, revenue sharing, and removal of under-used vehicles. In other words, a framework for self-regulation. It’s a start, not a bad thing.

@AsherOfLA @villi @jess You’re way off-base with that accusation. 15 mph is a software not hardware constraint. Scooters can go faster but impose the limit out of a concern for safety. I just want to treat bikes and scooters the same and give them both the best chance against cars.

If San Francisco really wants to be a city of the future, it should turn all metered street parking into protected bike/scooter lanes (15 mph max). It would transform the city overnight into one of the greenest and easiest to get around.

Progressives, for decades: “How do we get people out cars? They cause traffic, congestion, parking, pollution, accidents. We’ve tried carpool lanes, buses etc but nothing works.”
The solution arrives. 
“We might have to walk an extra six inches around it on a sidewalk? Ban it!!” https://t.co/OonAVhEgEb

text: Category defn is critical for enterprise products because of sales process. Customers want to go with market leader. Its a version of old adage “no one ever got fired for choosing IBM”. No one gets fired for choosing mkt leader. If you don’t define category, it’s hard to lead it. https://t.co/2puu6z0joG

@stevesi @lochhead I agree that you can’t force the category definition. It has to feel natural. ESN worked because it had a frame of reference in the consumer world. One test: when explaining what you do, does the category save you words? Good category definitions are concise and self-explanatory.
Defining our own category, rather than playing by the incumbent’s rules, made all the difference. More often than not, those who define the category win the category.
Yammer was acquired for $1.2B less than 4 years after launch. Meanwhile, leading “Social Software in the Workplace” products that had beat us to market by over 5 years fell by the wayside.

text: Category leadership helped confer legitimacy. We closed contracts with dozens of Fortune 500 companies. $25k pilots that we begged to close in Year 1 turned into $3M company-wide deployments in Year 3.
But they had the wrong architectures. They weren’t born cloud. They didn’t know how to engineer virality. Their offerings were clunky.
Our category definition caught on with the press. It was crisper and easier to understand. Soon our competitors were calling themselves Enterprise Social Networks.
We defined the key features around ease of use, signup and deployment resulting from our cloud freemium model. Our message was that without employee engagement, long feature checklists didn’t matter.
Instead we defined our own category: Enterprise Social Networking (“ESN”). We believed that’s what users wanted — a private secure social network for internal company use.
Gartner had a long list of feature requirements (like blogs and wikis) that we didn’t have. So instead of fighting for inclusion like most startups did, we fought to stay out of it.

Moore's Law alive and well in GPU industry.  https://t.co/lNTKmn5Xsa
@louhong Already happening. Underlying platforms for designing high-end graphics, games, and VR are all the same. VR emerged from gaming.
A misconception about VR future is that users will be semi-comatose like in Matrix. Actually physically demanding. Intensity will limit use.
Prediction 2: LA tech/ent ecosystem seriously competes with Silicon Valley to own VR future. (For example, Spielberg gets it.) cc @Jason
Prediction: VR will be the top seller for Christmas 2018. I agree that the mass market is about 2 years away. @Jason
@Jason The point is that it becomes really easy to see the future when you try the newer experiences. Bulky hardware & cost will be solved.
Some VCs who checked out VR a year or two ago are actually missing it now because they don't realize how much better the experience is.

text: 16/ I’m excited about the future of Zenefits and partnering with a great operator and our Board to take Zenefits to the next level. //
15/ I cannot thank all of our employees enough for their hard work to turn the company around. Their decisions and actions made it happen.

domain.name: Brand
domain.description: Brands and Companies

text: 14/ Z2 is also the best product in a huge greenfield category -- small business HR. With this, Zenefits is spring-loaded for success.

domain.name: Brand
domain.description: Brands and Companies

text: 13/ Zenefits has a great team, hundreds of millions of dollars in the bank, and years of runway to keep building.
12/ Now it is time to open a search for permanent CEO of the company. I will stay involved as Chairman, focusing on product and strategy.
11/ In short, we've achieved every goal set forth in my Day 1 memo, which outlined the turn-around plan.
10/ We refocused on our core small business market. We’ve seen renewed growth on the heels of Z2. Sales is hiring again.
9/ We reset our relationship with investors. We reduced headcount 35% and lowered monthly burn 50% YoY.
8/ Meanwhile, our amazing employees kept working. We launched our new Z2 product that small businesses love.
7/ As a result, the company now has a clean bill of health.
6/ Regulators across the country have praised the company for resetting its values, culture, mission, leadership, and governance.
5/ Remarkably CDI reduced its fine 50% in recognition of the remediation and cultural transformation we’ve done.
4/ This week we successfully resolved the issues with the California Department of Insurance (CDI), our lead regulator, and 19 other states.
3/ I accepted no compensation to do this job. (I wanted employees to get it all -- we more than doubled their ownership.)
2/ This is not a job I sought, but I felt a responsibility to investors, employees and customers to help the company through the crisis.

14/ For more info on the changes, please see my latest blog on how Zenefits is becoming the Compliance Company: 
https://t.co/3MEBDWM3Ph
13/ I hope reporters will take the time to see what we've actually accomplished and resist easy but inaccurate comparisons.
12/ In summary, Zenefits today is a different company that has addressed its historical issues and is looking to the future.
11/ As a result, our customer base (over 20,000) is sticking with us and ARR remains over $60M.
10/ Most of all, we have a real product that works for many thousands of small businesses who express appreciation and gratitude.
9/ Unlike others, we have made compliance a central part of our culture, values and expertise moving forward.

8/ Unlike others, we have agreed to accept responsibility for these historical issues.

https://t.co/oPqzzlci2m
7/ Unlike others, we proactively commissioned a Big Four accounting firm to audit our licensing and shared the result with regulators.
6/ Unlike others, we have stood up a robust compliance organization to prevent these issues from happening again.
5/ Unlike others, we reconstituted our board of directors to provide proper oversight and corporate governance.
4/ Unlike others, our founder/CEO agreed to step down, and we terminated execs who were part of the problem.
3/ Unlike others, we self-reported these historical licensing issues to regulators. We've been open and transparent about past failings.
2/ Unlike others, we have fixed our licensing issues. These are historical issues, not current ones. Today we are operating in compliance.

1/ Articles lumping in Zenefits with Theranos and others (without even talking with us) are lazy comparisons...
